displayed_text: Patient: I just want to be around a little bit longer, that’s all. Doctor: Well, our hope is that as well. Huh, my sense is, you know, these next drugs we, huh, huh, can get you a little bit more mileage, and you still haven’t had chemotherapy, which could get you some mileage. Huh, there’s an IV radiation drug that can get you a mileage. Most of it’s kicking the can down the street. Huh, we’ve got clinical trials at different points of new drugs, different drugs, combinations of drugs, huh, that we could think about. Huh, yes, so there’s a lot of things out there. It’s a matter of how much you want to go through, the rest of your body, your heart, the other things can get through because the next two drugs, we pick one of them. Huh, one of them is abiraterone, which is probably the cheaper of the two. It’s just gone generic. That doesn’t mean it’s cheap. Huh, but it’s about eleven, twelve thousand dollars a month. Huh, we check with your insurance carrier to see how much they cover. Huh, are you, huh, Medicare, Medicaid, huh, regular insurance, or-? Patient: Right now. Family Member: The next couple of days he’s regular insurance, but he’s going to get Medicare the first of March. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And that will help out. Patient: March first I start Medicare plus a supplement. Doctor: Yeah. Maybe with part D? Family Member: Yes. Patient: D and F, I think. Doctor: That would be great. So again, we may want to ask our pharmacy to look at the medicine next week once you’re on Medicare. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, because again, they will pay eighty percent.

Patient: Um, it’s gotten better. Definitely gotten better. There’s still, uh, the little lump here, like a cyst. So, saw the ear, nose, and uh, throat specialist, and I have that right here where it’s drained. So, he gave me some ointment, um, prescription ointment that I put on every day, a couple times a day. Uh, I go back to see him in January, and you know, he just said, you know, to monitor it and make sure if anything gets worse to call him immediately. Doctor: And do they think this is related to the teeth or? Patient: They think so. Yeah. Doctor: Do you know how long you’ve had that lump? Patient: Um, uh, it started in, in August, late August. I, I, can see that it shrunk. I can see… Doctor: Did they say it’s smaller? Patient: Much smaller, yeah. Doctor: Draining, or? Patient: Oh, yeah. It’ll drain a little bit, you know, every day. It’s kinda gotten, you can feel it’s a little hard right here, like a hard lump. Doctor: And you’re not on any antibiotics? Patient: No, no. So, they think it’s a combination of the Xgeva and the, uh, oral surgery I had a year ago. Doctor: Anything else going on?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, cool. Alright so next time I see you will be on the twenty eighth. His PSA wasn’t bad was it? Healthcare Professional: Down, down from so… Doctor: Just slightly down. Healthcare Professional: So slightly down. Doctor: Okay, it’s heading in the right direction. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: It went a tiny bit down so. Patient: That’s good to hear. Doctor: Um hm. Absolutely. Patient: I was wondering, they said theys gon’ have cameras on. Doctor: Today? Healthcare Professional: Yeah.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We also sort of know what side effects you’re going to experience to sort of see whether you can tolerate this. We have to adjust the doses about that. So that’s an approved drug that’s known to extend survival if people get the drugs, tolerate the drugs, respond to the drugs. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know those people can do well compared to those who don’t respond or don’t get the drug. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So chemo would be something that you know it could be given here, it could be given there, but it’s standard treatment. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have a clinical trial where we’re giving the chemotherapy and everybody gets an infusion two to three times a week. So- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: for someone coming from F___ may it may be too much to come in here that often, but we’re giving Vitamin C to half the people and half the people don’t because some data says that Vitamin C may reduce the side effects of the chemotherapy and also help the benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But we don’t know that. It could be just folly; it could be the truth-

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: and see where things are at. Okay? That way I’ll be able to see if we need to put you back on the medication. Family Member: I think that’s a good idea. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But that’s not a crutch either to say I’m back on Metformin I can eat cookies. Patient: Oh, oh… Family Member: Because I buy sugar free cookies every now and then. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. Family Member: He’s not doing bad because I’ve seen him worse. Doctor: This is much better than Family Member: Yeah Doctor: what we started off in. He was, you were mighty sick when we started so.

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …and it would show probably very small areas. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um and those are non-targetable. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that’s just the – the struggle is unless that thing whichever one decides to block anything off… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …we tend to treat it systemically. Patient: Okay. Doctor: …with pills or IV or whatnot which we’ll talk about. So I don’t want to cut you open, but I do want to re-biopsy you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and I talked to our radiologist. He’s gonna see at the time that you’re on the table of the CAT scan what is the best area to target because these things all move as well. Patient: Mhmm.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Huh, so are you finished with that? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. And then so you’re still taking the abiraterone four pills a day? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, the acyclovir is the one that they’ve asked you to take for ten days, probably for this? Huh, the Dulcolax to help for constipation? The Natural Tears now for your eye? The iron pill one, huh, three times a day? Patient: Yep. Well. Doctor: The ibuprofen as needed? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The lisinopril with the water pill in it, one pill a day? Patient: Right. Doctor: And you’ve got your tapazole, huh, methimazole. Doctor: Morphine. You’ve got, huh, fifteen milligrams as needed? Your multivitamin once a day?

Patient: Okay as far as working what do you mean by that? I mean is it something… Doctor: Working against – shrinking the cancer and helping – working against the… Family Member: Targeting drugs and genes (doc and fam talking at the same time.) Doctor: Targeting exactly the cancer that you have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now there is another option, I know you’re completely reluctant to go on chemotherapy. You know there is obviously that would be the standard treatment that you know we would – if we advise that and if you decide you want that you could easily get it in lots and closer to home. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: But there is a newer hormonal therapy that also we can consider for you. Now that is sort of an earlier phase trial, so it’s a phase one trial. Okay. But the advantage is that we’ve already been through a number of the dosing levels. So typically a phase one trial is where you’re getting something very new that’s worked amazingly well in the lab that now you’re testing in people. So the first few dose levels really are trying to see what kind of side effects and what dose level really has… Patient: Sure. Doctor: But you’ll have some long days and things like that, you would have the hotel and mileage covered you know same as this study for that matter. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. (clears throat) Doctor: So those things would be covered, but it is a matter of whether you’re willing to come back and forth.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So if someone has an intermediate or low Gleason score, the PSA level is less than fifty it’s rising at a slow pace… it’s better after six months. to start the hormone therapy. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Unless, the PSA or Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But to me if it’s a combination of both factors. Again, if you ever have a symptom from your cancer, then typically that is what I would strongly recommend. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So stopping with the clinical trial therapy and preceding with non-hormonal therapy. time to try something else. Patient: And that would be the … Doctor: That would be the example. Patient: Okay. Can you tell me my Gleason score? Doctor: Your Gleason score was a seven out of ten and that was based on your in two thousand and seven.

Patient: Right, right.. Doctor: Like every single time when you started the first day I met you we’re always behind the cancer. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Stuff happens and I’m reactive. Patient: Stop doctor, we’re not saying that word no more. Doctor: Sorry about that. We’re always behind the thing. Patient: The thing, yes. Doctor: However, what we need to do is get ahead of it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So we’ve got the Provenge in. I think there’s another set of pills, these are FDA approved. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It is not experimental. Patient: Right.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: “Hello, I’m Mr. P___ I'm on two of Xtandi”. Patient: Yes. Doctor: PSA is starting to do this, uh-oh, we're kind of worried. So, sometimes the cancer gets smart. And now we say look, maybe there's a way to kind of flap that, see if we can get it to work again, because it did work for a while, which was good. So this pill going right along, we want to add a second pill. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: This study is to add a second pill, different pathway, to say hey, I'm gonna see if I add the second guy whether both together will make your PSA drop. But of course, to make things complicated, the second pill, they want to do stuff too. So they're going to have two groups. So if you're in the first group, you keep going on your Xtandi, and you get the second pill at a particular dose, no problem. Then W____ is on the same study, he's on Xtandi two pills a day. And I give him also the second pill at the same dose. Nobody's placebo-ing, you're now on two potentially active medicines, okay. But to make the study even more interesting, what they're doing is, if you are doing okay, on those two doses, they're going to give you an extra, you know, like 40 milligrams every month to see if they can increase that dose to get better mileage on this activity. But W____ is going to also get a matching pill. But his is not an active 40 milligrams, he just gets the sugar version of the 40 milligrams. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But everybody's on the second pill at the right dose, and the Xtandi. ‘ Patient: Okay, I think I understand that. Okay. Doctor: Yes. And if you try to look on the internet, it's not the way it is, they just literally opened this up. So when M____, who was one that was calling you, she just wanted to know if you are even interested. Because if so we would have to get a spot. And then when you come in, you see a W____ equivalent, but just somebody who knows that study better. Kind of like a M____ and a W____hybrid. And you would be seen across the hall in our other area, but you still have me you can't get rid of me. And then we just decide if this is the right thing or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The alternative would be you know, let's say you're not eligible or you're not interested, we would try a different study to see; we would get off that Xtandi and try something else. I just said, “Well you are already on the 80 maybe we can get this guy come back and do more.” So that's an option, but there are still more options. So I don't want you to worry if that one is not going to work or is not appealing. We got more options. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Right. Okay. So then if the hemoglobin is not sufficient when he comes back, for example, he gets the transfusion, he gets here, and do the lab or something, so if it’s not, then what happens? Doctor: Uh, I mean, I’ll have to look at the protocol to see, you know, what the rules are about how long the drug can be delayed. But one option would be to call it quits at that point in time and talk about additional therapies, new therapies. The second option would be to keep him off the drug for the maximum amount of time before the study, you know, would kick him out, and then to hope and pray and, and maybe even give another transfusion to make the hemoglobin. If you’re trying that hard to make the hemoglobin not drop, it probably means that it’s not in the best interest of the patient to stay on the study. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So let’s cross that bridge if we get to it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, but it will not be a very good sign if despite coming off the drug and the transfusion, the hemoglobin still drops. So after that point, we have a more detailed discussion about alternative options. Patient: Yes. Doctor: But let’s hope for the best. Patient: We’ll be in our faith, so we’ll keep on looking up. Doctor: Me too. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that makes two of us. Patient: Okay. We’re done? I think we got it okay. I want to make sure.

Patient: Yeah.This may not be a question for you. But if I were to retire- Doctor: Mhm. Patient: I'm not sure. I'm not sure what kind of health care insurance I'm gonna have. Doctor: Okay, yeah. Patient: Yeah, but, is so I don't know have you- I don’t know how to ask the question. So is there assistance available? If I would need it if I changed to a different insurance. Doctor: You mean as per trial or in general Patient: Just in general, I guess. Doctor: Yeah, I think you know, before you make any switch, I would say we touch base, have you touch base with our financial counselors to make sure that you're optimized with everything. I mean, you know, trying to think how old are you? Patient: How old am I? Patient: The older you get the harder it is to remember. I'll be 64 in November. Doctor: So when you qualify for Medicare, is it now or you have to be 65? Patient: I'm the lazy investor.

Family Member: Hi. Nice to see you. Doctor: So, you know, you done good. Family Member: It got better. Doctor: How about that? Family Member: Good news. No new treatments. Doctor: Yeah. I think you get a break for six weeks until I torture you with that, I mean help you, again. Family Member: What’s that going to involve? Patient: What’s going to happen in six weeks? Doctor: Nothing. I just want to make sure your PSA isn’t like skyrocketing. (Door sound) Patient: Oh. Doctor: You know? Ten, ten is okay. Patient: Oh, ten isn’t climbing?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Um. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So it just lets me be aware that I’ve got to be extra careful I’m giving you the chemotherapy. But it could be the one thing that sort of says oh he’s not eligible because he’s got a tube in his body. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Or maybe they don’t care one bit. Patient: Um. Doctor: So that’s what D___ and I will work on. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. So I’ll to go - Doctor: Well then let me; I think she’s out here but I know she will have been in touch with you, but I think she wanted me to clear you today to say hey, that she’s still a candidate because his blood tests have improved and acts with – PSA isn’t bad. Okay. Uh are there questions that you guys have? So we talked about diet; we talked about Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But right now they’re going to spend a little bit more time seeing if the trial makes sense for you –
